         </div>Plaque of the <a href="/wiki/Rights_of_man" class="mw-redirect" title="Rights of man">Rights of man</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Crown_colony_of_Malta" class="mw-redirect" title="Crown colony of Malta">British Protectorate</a> (1802) at <a href="/wiki/Palazzo_Parisio_(Valletta)" title="Palazzo Parisio (Valletta)">Palazzo Parisio</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:BombDamageMalta.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/BombDamageMalta.jpg/220px-BombDamageMalta.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="167" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/BombDamageMalta.jpg/330px-BombDamageMalta.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/BombDamageMalta.jpg/440px-BombDamageMalta.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="606"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:BombDamageMalta.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The heavily bomb-damaged Kingsway (now Republic Street) in <a href="/wiki/Valletta" title="Valletta">Valletta</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Malta_(World_War_II)" title="Siege of Malta (World War II)">Siege of Malta</a>, 1942
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 1814, as part of the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Paris_(1814)" title="Treaty of Paris (1814)">Treaty of Paris</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-stbenedict_116-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-stbenedict-116">[116]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-DIC_11_120-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DIC_11-120">[120]</a></sup> Malta officially became a part of the <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British Empire</a> and was used as a shipping way-station and fleet headquarters. After the <a href="/wiki/Suez_Canal" title="Suez Canal">Suez Canal</a> opened in 1869, Malta's position halfway between the <a href="/wiki/Strait_of_Gibraltar" title="Strait of Gibraltar">Strait of Gibraltar</a> and Egypt proved to be its main asset, and it was considered an important stop on the way to India, a central trade route for the British. </p>
      <p>A <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Military_Cemetery" title="Turkish Military Cemetery">Turkish Military Cemetery</a> was commissioned by <a href="/wiki/Sultan_Abdul_Aziz" class="mw-redirect" title="Sultan Abdul Aziz">Sultan Abdul Aziz</a> and built between 1873-1874 for the fallen Ottoman soldiers of the <a href="/wiki/Great_Siege_of_Malta" title="Great Siege of Malta">Great Siege of Malta</a>. </p>
      <p>Between 1915 and 1918, during the <a href="/wiki/First_World_War" class="mw-redirect" title="First World War">First World War</a>, Malta became known as <i>the Nurse of the Mediterranean</i> due to the large number of wounded soldiers who were accommodated in Malta.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">[121]</a></sup> In 1919 British troops fired into a crowd protesting against new taxes, killing four. The event, known as <a href="/wiki/Sette_Giugno" title="Sette Giugno">Sette Giugno</a> (Italian for <i>7 June</i>), is commemorated every year and is one of five National Days.<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">[122]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">[123]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Before the <a href="/wiki/Second_World_War" class="mw-redirect" title="Second World War">Second World War</a>, Valletta was the location of the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Navy" title="Royal Navy">Royal Navy</a>'s <a href="/wiki/British_Mediterranean_Fleet" class="mw-redirect" title="British Mediterranean Fleet">Mediterranean Fleet</a>'s headquarters; however, despite <a href="/wiki/Winston_Churchill" title="Winston Churchill">Winston Churchill</a>'s objections,<sup id="cite_ref-BJandCS-p36_124-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BJandCS-p36-124">[124]</a></sup> the command was moved to <a href="/wiki/Alexandria" title="Alexandria">Alexandria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Egypt" title="Egypt">Egypt</a>, in April 1937 out of fear that it was too susceptible to air attacks from Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-BJandCS-p36_124-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BJandCS-p36-124">[124]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">[125]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ElliottP--pxx_126-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ElliottP--pxx-126">[126]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>During the Second World War, Malta played an important role for the <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II" title="Allies of World War II">Allies</a>; being a British colony, situated close to Sicily and the <a href="/wiki/Axis_Powers" class="mw-redirect" title="Axis Powers">Axis</a> shipping lanes, Malta was bombarded by the Italian and German air forces. Malta was used by the British to launch attacks on the Italian navy and had a submarine base. It was also used as a listening post, intercepting German radio messages including <a href="/wiki/Enigma_(machine)" class="mw-redirect" title="Enigma (machine)">Enigma</a> traffic.<sup id="cite_ref-CP-p42-44_127-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CP-p42-44-127">[127]</a></sup> The bravery of the Maltese people during the second <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Malta_(World_War_II)" title="Siege of Malta (World War II)">Siege of Malta</a> moved <a href="/wiki/King_George_VI" class="mw-redirect" title="King George VI">King George VI</a> to <a href="/wiki/Award_of_the_George_Cross_to_Malta" title="Award of the George Cross to Malta">award</a> the <a href="/wiki/George_Cross" title="George Cross">George Cross</a> to Malta on a collective basis on 15 April 1942 "to bear witness to a heroism and devotion that will long be famous in history". Some historians argue that the award caused Britain to incur disproportionate losses in defending Malta, as British credibility would have suffered if Malta had surrendered, <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Singapore" title="Battle of Singapore">as British forces in Singapore had done</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">[128]</a></sup> A depiction of the George Cross now appears in the upper hoist corner of the <a href="/wiki/Flag_of_Malta" title="Flag of Malta">Flag of Malta</a> and on the country's <a href="/wiki/Coat_of_arms_of_Malta" title="Coat of arms of Malta">arms</a>. The collective award remained unique until April 1999, when the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Ulster_Constabulary" title="Royal Ulster Constabulary">Royal Ulster Constabulary</a> became the second&nbsp;â and, to date, the only other&nbsp;â recipient of a collective George Cross.<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">[129]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Independence_and_Republic">Independence and Republic</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: Independence and Republic">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/State_of_Malta" title="State of Malta">State of Malta</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Denkmal_an_die_Unabh%C3%A4ngigkeit_Maltas_in_Valletta.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Denkmal_an_die_Unabh%C3%A4ngigkeit_Maltas_in_Valletta.jpg/220px-Denkmal_an_die_Unabh%C3%A4ngigkeit_Maltas_in_Valletta.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Denkmal_an_die_Unabh%C3%A4ngigkeit_Maltas_in_Valletta.jpg/330px-Denkmal_an_die_Unabh%C3%A4ngigkeit_Maltas_in_Valletta.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Denkmal_an_die_Unabh%C3%A4ngigkeit_Maltas_in_Valletta.jpg/440px-Denkmal_an_die_Unabh%C3%A4ngigkeit_Maltas_in_Valletta.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3888" data-file-height="2592"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Denkmal_an_die_Unabh%C3%A4ngigkeit_Maltas_in_Valletta.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Monument to the independence of Malta in <a href="/wiki/Floriana" title="Floriana">Floriana</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_(081).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg/220px-Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="131" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg/330px-Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg/440px-Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="521" data-file-height="310"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_(081).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Malta joined the European Union in 2004 and signed the <a href="/wiki/Lisbon_Treaty" class="mw-redirect" title="Lisbon Treaty">Lisbon Treaty</a> in 2007.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Malta achieved its independence as the <a href="/wiki/State_of_Malta" title="State of Malta">State of Malta</a> on 21 September 1964 (<a href="/wiki/Independence_Day_(Malta)" title="Independence Day (Malta)">Independence Day</a>) after intense negotiations with the United Kingdom, led by Maltese Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/George_Bor%C4%A1_Olivier" class="mw-redirect" title="George BorÄ¡ Olivier">George BorÄ¡ Olivier</a>. Under its 1964 constitution, Malta initially retained Queen <a href="/wiki/Elizabeth_II_of_the_United_Kingdom" class="mw-redirect" title="Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom">Elizabeth II</a> as <a href="/wiki/Queen_of_Malta" title="Queen of Malta">Queen of Malta</a> and thus <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a>, with a <a href="/wiki/Governor-general" title="Governor-general">governor-general</a> exercising executive authority on her behalf. In 1971, the <a href="/wiki/Malta_Labour_Party" class="mw-redirect" title="Malta Labour Party">Malta Labour Party</a> led by <a href="/wiki/Dom_Mintoff" title="Dom Mintoff">Dom Mintoff</a> won the general elections, resulting in Malta declaring itself a republic on 13 December 1974 (<a href="/wiki/Republic_Day_(Malta)" title="Republic Day (Malta)">Republic Day</a>) within the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations" title="Commonwealth of Nations">Commonwealth</a>, with the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Malta" title="President of Malta">President</a> as <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a>. A defence agreement was signed soon after independence, and after being re-negotiated in 1972, expired on 31 March 1979.<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[130]</a></sup> Upon its expiry, the British base closed down and all lands formerly controlled by the British on the island were given up to the Maltese government.<sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131">[131]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Malta adopted a policy of <a href="/wiki/Neutral_country" title="Neutral country">neutrality</a> in 1980.<sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">[132]</a></sup> In 1989, Malta was the venue of a <a href="/wiki/Malta_Summit" title="Malta Summit">summit</a> between US President <a href="/wiki/George_H.W._Bush" class="mw-redirect" title="George H.W. Bush">George H.W. Bush</a> and Soviet leader <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Gorbachev" title="Mikhail Gorbachev">Mikhail Gorbachev</a>, their first face-to-face encounter, which signalled the end of the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">[133]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>On 16 July 1990, Malta, through its foreign minister, <a href="/wiki/Guido_de_Marco" title="Guido de Marco">Guido de Marco</a>, applied to join the European Union.<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">[134]</a></sup> After tough negotiations, a referendum was held on 8 March 2003, which resulted in a favourable vote.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[135]</a></sup> General Elections held on 12 April 2003, gave a clear mandate to the Prime Minister, <a href="/wiki/Eddie_Fenech_Adami" title="Eddie Fenech Adami">Eddie Fenech Adami</a>, to sign the treaty of accession to the European Union on 16 April 2003 in <a href="/wiki/Athens" title="Athens">Athens</a>, Greece.<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[136]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Malta joined the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> on 1 May 2004.<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">[137]</a></sup> Following the European Council of 21â22 June 2007, Malta joined the <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">eurozone</a> on 1 January 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">[138]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">Politics</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: Politics">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <table class="box-More_citations_needed_section plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Refimprove" role="presentation">
       <tbody>
        <tr>
         <td class="mbox-image">
          <div style="width:52px">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png" decoding="async" width="50" height="39" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/75px-Question_book-new.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/100px-Question_book-new.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="399"></a>
          </div></td>
         <td class="mbox-text">
          <div class="mbox-text-span">
           This section <b>needs additional citations for <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">verification</a></b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please help <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit">improve this article</a> by <a href="/wiki/Help:Referencing_for_beginners" title="Help:Referencing for beginners">adding citations to reliable sources</a>. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed.</span> <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">September 2017</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small>
          </div></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Malta_Valletta_BW_2011-10-07_10-41-05.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Malta_Valletta_BW_2011-10-07_10-41-05.JPG/220px-Malta_Valletta_BW_2011-10-07_10-41-05.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Malta_Valletta_BW_2011-10-07_10-41-05.JPG/330px-Malta_Valletta_BW_2011-10-07_10-41-05.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Malta_Valletta_BW_2011-10-07_10-41-05.JPG/440px-Malta_Valletta_BW_2011-10-07_10-41-05.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3431" data-file-height="2566"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Malta_Valletta_BW_2011-10-07_10-41-05.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Courts_of_Justice_building_(Valletta)" title="Courts of Justice building (Valletta)">Courts of Justice building</a> in <a href="/wiki/Valletta" title="Valletta">Valletta</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Malta" title="Politics of Malta">Politics of Malta</a>, <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Malta" title="Government of Malta">Government of Malta</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Law_of_Malta" title="Law of Malta">Law of Malta</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Malta is a <a href="/wiki/Republic" title="Republic">republic</a><sup id="cite_ref-constitution_25-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-constitution-25">[25]</a></sup> whose <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_system" title="Parliamentary system">parliamentary system</a> and <a href="/wiki/Public_administration" title="Public administration">public administration</a> are closely modelled on the <a href="/wiki/Westminster_system" title="Westminster system">Westminster system</a>. Malta had the second-highest <a href="/wiki/Voter_turnout" title="Voter turnout">voter turnout</a> in the world (and the highest for nations without <a href="/wiki/Mandatory_voting" class="mw-redirect" title="Mandatory voting">mandatory voting</a>), based on election turnout in national <a href="/wiki/Lower_house" title="Lower house">lower house</a> elections from 1960 to 1995.<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">[139]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Unicameral" class="mw-redirect" title="Unicameral">unicameral</a> Parliament is made up of the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Malta" title="President of Malta">President of Malta</a> and the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Representatives_of_Malta" class="mw-redirect" title="House of Representatives of Malta">House of Representatives</a> (<a href="/wiki/Maltese_language" title="Maltese language">Maltese</a>: <i lang="mt">Kamra tad-Deputati</i>). The President of Malta, a largely ceremonial position, is appointed for a five-year term by a resolution of the House of Representatives carried by a simple majority. Members of the House of Representatives are elected by direct universal suffrage through <a href="/wiki/Single_transferable_vote" title="Single transferable vote">single transferable vote</a> every five years, unless the House is dissolved earlier by the president either on the advice of the <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Malta" title="Prime Minister of Malta">prime minister</a> or through the adoption of a motion of no confidence carried within the House of Representatives and not overturned within three days. In either of these cases, the president may alternatively choose to invite another Member of Parliament who invariably should command the majority of the House of Representatives to form an alternative government for the remainder of the legislature. </p>
      <p>The House of Representatives is nominally made up of 65 members of parliament whereby 5 members of parliament are elected from each of the thirteen electoral districts. However, where a party wins an absolute majority of votes but does not have a majority of seats, that party is given additional seats to ensure a parliamentary majority. The 80th article of the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Malta" title="Constitution of Malta">Constitution of Malta</a> provides that the president appoint as prime minister "... the member of the House of Representatives who, in his judgment, is best able to command the support of a majority of the members of that House".<sup id="cite_ref-constitution_25-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-constitution-25">[25]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Maltese politics is a <a href="/wiki/Two-party_system" title="Two-party system">two-party system</a> dominated by the <a href="/wiki/Labour_Party_(Malta)" title="Labour Party (Malta)">Labour Party</a> (<a href="/wiki/Maltese_language" title="Maltese language">Maltese</a>: <i lang="mt">Partit Laburista</i>), a centre-left <a href="/wiki/Social_democracy" title="Social democracy">social democratic</a> party, and the <a href="/wiki/Nationalist_Party_(Malta)" title="Nationalist Party (Malta)">Nationalist Party</a> (<a href="/wiki/Maltese_language" title="Maltese language">Maltese</a>: <i lang="mt">Partit Nazzjonalista</i>), a centre-right <a href="/wiki/Christian_democracy" title="Christian democracy">Christian democratic</a> party. The Labour Party has been the governing party since 2013 and is currently led by Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Robert_Abela" title="Robert Abela">Robert Abela</a>, who has been in office since 13 January 2020. The Nationalist Party, with <a href="/wiki/Bernard_Grech" title="Bernard Grech">Bernard Grech</a> as its leader, is currently in opposition. Two parliamentary seats are held by <a href="/wiki/Independent_politician" title="Independent politician">independent politicians</a> who were formerly with the <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Party_(Malta)" title="Democratic Party (Malta)">Democratic Party</a> (<a href="/wiki/Maltese_language" title="Maltese language">Maltese</a>: <i lang="mt">Partit Demokratiku</i>), a centre-left <a href="/wiki/Social_liberalism" title="Social liberalism">social liberal</a> party which had contested under the Nationalist-led <a href="/wiki/Forza_Nazzjonali" title="Forza Nazzjonali">Forza Nazzjonali</a> electoral alliance in 2017. There are a number of small political parties in Malta which have no parliamentary representation. </p>
      <p>Until the <a href="/wiki/Second_World_War" class="mw-redirect" title="Second World War">Second World War</a>, Maltese politics was dominated by the <a href="/wiki/Language_Question_(Malta)" title="Language Question (Malta)">Language Question</a> fought out by <a href="/wiki/Italophone" class="mw-redirect" title="Italophone">Italophone</a> and <a href="/wiki/Anglophone" class="mw-redirect" title="Anglophone">Anglophone</a> parties.<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">[140]</a></sup> Post-war politics dealt with constitutional questions on the relations with Britain (first with <a href="/wiki/Maltese_integration_into_the_United_Kingdom_referendum,_1956" class="mw-redirect" title="Maltese integration into the United Kingdom referendum, 1956">integration</a> then <a href="/wiki/Independence_Day_(Malta)" title="Independence Day (Malta)">independence</a>) and, eventually, <a href="/wiki/History_of_Malta#The_accession_process_to_the_European_Union_(1987â2004)" title="History of Malta">relations with the European Union</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: Administrative divisions">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Local_councils_of_Malta" title="Local councils of Malta">Local councils of Malta</a>, <a href="/wiki/Districts_of_Malta" title="Districts of Malta">Districts of Malta</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Regions_of_Malta" title="Regions of Malta">Regions of Malta</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Malta_-_administrative_division.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Malta_-_administrative_division.svg/220px-Malta_-_administrative_division.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Malta_-_administrative_division.svg/330px-Malta_-_administrative_division.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Malta_-_administrative_division.svg/440px-Malta_-_administrative_division.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="600"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Malta_-_administrative_division.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Local_councils_of_Malta" title="Local councils of Malta">Administrative divisions</a> of Malta
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Malta has had a system of local government since 1993,<sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">[141]</a></sup> based on the <a href="/wiki/European_Charter_of_Local_Self-Government" title="European Charter of Local Self-Government">European Charter of Local Self-Government</a>. The country is divided into <a href="/wiki/Regions_of_Malta" title="Regions of Malta">five regions</a> (one of them being Gozo), with each region having its own Regional Committee, serving as the intermediate level between local government and national government.<sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">[142]</a></sup> The regions are divided into <a href="/wiki/Local_councils_of_Malta" title="Local councils of Malta">local councils</a>, of which there are currently 68 (54 in Malta and 14 in <a href="/wiki/Gozo" title="Gozo">Gozo</a>). The <a href="/wiki/Districts_of_Malta" title="Districts of Malta">six districts</a> (five on Malta and the sixth being Gozo) serve primarily statistical purposes.<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">[143]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Each council is made up of a number of councillors (from 5 to 13, depending on and relative to the population they represent). A mayor and a <a href="/wiki/Deputy_mayor" title="Deputy mayor">deputy mayor</a> are elected by and from the councillors. The executive secretary, who is appointed by the council, is the executive, administrative and financial head of the council. Councillors are elected every four years through the <a href="/wiki/Single_transferable_vote" title="Single transferable vote">single transferable vote</a>. People who are eligible to vote in the election of the Maltese <a href="/wiki/House_of_Representatives_of_Malta" class="mw-redirect" title="House of Representatives of Malta">House of Representatives</a> as well as a resident <a href="/wiki/Citizenship_of_the_European_Union" title="Citizenship of the European Union">citizens of the EU</a> are eligible to vote. Due to system reforms, no elections were held before 2012. Since then, elections have been held every two years for an alternating half of the councils. </p>
      <p>Local councils are responsible for the general upkeep and embellishment of the locality (including repairs to non-arterial roads), allocation of local wardens, and refuse collection; they also carry out general administrative duties for the central government such as the collection of government rents and funds and answer government-related public inquiries. Additionally, a number of individual towns and villages in the Republic of Malta have <a href="/wiki/List_of_twin_towns_and_sister_cities_in_Malta" title="List of twin towns and sister cities in Malta">sister cities</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Military">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Armed_Forces_of_Malta" title="Armed Forces of Malta">Armed Forces of Malta</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:US_Navy_111205-N-FV216-139_The_Armed_Forces_of_Malta_counter_piracy_vessel_protection_detachment_demonstrates_aerial_boarding_procedures_during_Eur.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/US_Navy_111205-N-FV216-139_The_Armed_Forces_of_Malta_counter_piracy_vessel_protection_detachment_demonstrates_aerial_boarding_procedures_during_Eur.jpg/220px-US_Navy_111205-N-FV216-139_The_Armed_Forces_of_Malta_counter_piracy_vessel_protection_detachment_demonstrates_aerial_boarding_procedures_during_Eur.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/US_Navy_111205-N-FV216-139_The_Armed_Forces_of_Malta_counter_piracy_vessel_protection_detachment_demonstrates_aerial_boarding_procedures_during_Eur.jpg/330px-US_Navy_111205-N-FV216-139_The_Armed_Forces_of_Malta_counter_piracy_vessel_protection_detachment_demonstrates_aerial_boarding_procedures_during_Eur.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/US_Navy_111205-N-FV216-139_The_Armed_Forces_of_Malta_counter_piracy_vessel_protection_detachment_demonstrates_aerial_boarding_procedures_during_Eur.jpg/440px-US_Navy_111205-N-FV216-139_The_Armed_Forces_of_Malta_counter_piracy_vessel_protection_detachment_demonstrates_aerial_boarding_procedures_during_Eur.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4145" data-file-height="2770"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:US_Navy_111205-N-FV216-139_The_Armed_Forces_of_Malta_counter_piracy_vessel_protection_detachment_demonstrates_aerial_boarding_procedures_during_Eur.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Protector-class_coastal_patrol_boat" title="Protector-class coastal patrol boat"><i>Protector</i>-class patrol boats</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Maritime_Squadron_of_the_Armed_Forces_of_Malta" title="Maritime Squadron of the Armed Forces of Malta">Maritime Squadron of the AFM</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The objectives of the Armed Forces of Malta (AFM) are to maintain a military organisation with the primary aim of defending the islands' integrity according to the defence roles as set by the government in an efficient and cost-effective manner. This is achieved by emphasising the maintenance of Malta's territorial waters and airspace integrity.<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">[144]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The AFM also engages in combating terrorism, fighting against illicit drug trafficking, conducting anti-illegal immigrant operations and patrols, and anti-illegal fishing operations, operating <a href="/wiki/Search_and_rescue" title="Search and rescue">search and rescue</a> (SAR) services, and physical or electronic security and surveillance of sensitive locations. Malta's search-and-rescue area extends from east of <a href="/wiki/Tunisia" title="Tunisia">Tunisia</a> to west of <a href="/wiki/Crete" title="Crete">Crete</a>, covering an area of around 250,000&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (97,000&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi).<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[145]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>As a military organisation, the AFM provides backup support to the <a href="/wiki/Malta_Police_Force" title="Malta Police Force">Malta Police Force</a> (MPF) and other government departments/agencies in situations as required in an organised, disciplined manner in the event of national emergencies (such as natural disasters) or internal security and bomb disposal.<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">[146]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2020, Malta signed and ratified the UN <a href="/wiki/Treaty_on_the_Prohibition_of_Nuclear_Weapons" title="Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons">treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">[147]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">[148]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: Geography">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Malta" title="Geography of Malta">Geography of Malta</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:General_map_of_Malta.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/General_map_of_Malta.svg/220px-General_map_of_Malta.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="190" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/General_map_of_Malta.svg/330px-General_map_of_Malta.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/General_map_of_Malta.svg/440px-General_map_of_Malta.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="502" data-file-height="433"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:General_map_of_Malta.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Topographic map of Malta
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Malta is an <a href="/wiki/Archipelago" title="Archipelago">archipelago</a> in the central <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean" class="mw-redirect" title="Mediterranean">Mediterranean</a> (in its <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Mediterranean" title="Eastern Mediterranean">eastern basin</a>), some 80&nbsp;km (50&nbsp;mi) from southern <a href="/wiki/Italy" title="Italy">Italy</a> across the <a href="/wiki/Malta_Channel" title="Malta Channel">Malta Channel</a>. Only the three largest islands&nbsp;â <a href="/wiki/Malta_Island" class="mw-redirect" title="Malta Island">Malta</a> (Malta), <a href="/wiki/Gozo" title="Gozo">Gozo</a> (GÄ§awdex) and <a href="/wiki/Comino" title="Comino">Comino</a> (Kemmuna)&nbsp;â are inhabited. The islands of the archipelago lie on the Malta plateau, a shallow shelf formed from the high points of a <a href="/wiki/Land_bridge" title="Land bridge">land bridge</a> between Sicily and North Africa that became isolated as sea levels rose after the last <a href="/wiki/Ice_Age" class="mw-redirect" title="Ice Age">Ice Age</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">[149]</a></sup> The archipelago is located on the African tectonic plate.<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[150]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[151]</a></sup> Malta was considered an island of North Africa for centuries.<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">[152]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Numerous bays along the indented coastline of the islands provide good harbours. The landscape consists of low hills with terraced fields. The highest point in Malta is <a href="/wiki/Ta%27_Dmejrek" title="Ta' Dmejrek">Ta' Dmejrek</a>, at 253&nbsp;m (830&nbsp;ft), near <a href="/wiki/Dingli" title="Dingli">Dingli</a>. Although there are some small rivers at times of high rainfall, there are no permanent rivers or lakes on Malta. However, some watercourses have fresh water running all year round at <a href="/wiki/Ba%C4%A7rija" title="BaÄ§rija">BaÄ§rija</a> near <a href="/wiki/Ras_ir-Ra%C4%A7eb" title="Ras ir-RaÄ§eb">Ras ir-RaÄ§eb</a>, at l-ImtaÄ§leb and San Martin, and at Lunzjata Valley in Gozo. </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Phytogeography" title="Phytogeography">Phytogeographically</a>, Malta belongs to the Liguro-Tyrrhenian province of the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Region" class="mw-redirect" title="Mediterranean Region">Mediterranean Region</a> within the <a href="/wiki/Boreal_Kingdom" title="Boreal Kingdom">Boreal Kingdom</a>. According to the <a href="/wiki/World_Wide_Fund_for_Nature" title="World Wide Fund for Nature">WWF</a>, the territory of Malta belongs to the terrestrial <a href="/wiki/Ecoregion" title="Ecoregion">ecoregion</a> of <a href="/wiki/Tyrrhenian-Adriatic_sclerophyllous_and_mixed_forests" title="Tyrrhenian-Adriatic sclerophyllous and mixed forests">Tyrrhenian-Adriatic sclerophyllous and mixed forests</a><sup id="cite_ref-DinersteinOlson2017_153-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DinersteinOlson2017-153">[153]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Malta_-_Mgarr_(Fort_Bingemma_)_01_ies.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Malta_-_Mgarr_%28Fort_Bingemma_%29_01_ies.jpg/220px-Malta_-_Mgarr_%28Fort_Bingemma_%29_01_ies.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Malta_-_Mgarr_%28Fort_Bingemma_%29_01_ies.jpg/330px-Malta_-_Mgarr_%28Fort_Bingemma_%29_01_ies.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Malta_-_Mgarr_%28Fort_Bingemma_%29_01_ies.jpg/440px-Malta_-_Mgarr_%28Fort_Bingemma_%29_01_ies.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5616" data-file-height="3744"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Malta_-_Mgarr_(Fort_Bingemma_)_01_ies.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Maltese landscape, <a href="/wiki/M%C4%A1arr" title="MÄ¡arr">MÄ¡arr</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The minor islands that form part of the archipelago are uninhabited and include: </p> 
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r998391716">.mw-parser-output .div-col{margin-top:0.3em;column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .div-col-small{font-size:90%}.mw-parser-output .div-col-rules{column-rule:1px solid #aaa}.mw-parser-output .div-col dl,.mw-parser-output .div-col ol,.mw-parser-output .div-col ul{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .div-col li,.mw-parser-output .div-col dd{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}</style>
      <div class="div-col" style="column-width: 30em;"> 
       <ul>
        <li>BarbaÄ¡anni Rock (<a href="/wiki/Gozo" title="Gozo">Gozo</a>)</li> 
        <li><a href="/wiki/Cominotto" title="Cominotto">Cominotto</a>, (<i>Kemmunett</i>)</li> 
        <li>Dellimara Island (<a href="/wiki/Marsaxlokk" title="Marsaxlokk">Marsaxlokk</a>)</li> 
        <li><a href="/wiki/Filfla" title="Filfla">Filfla</a> (<a href="/wiki/%C5%BBurrieq" title="Å»urrieq">Å»urrieq</a>)/(<a href="/wiki/Si%C4%A1%C4%A1iewi" title="SiÄ¡Ä¡iewi">SiÄ¡Ä¡iewi</a>)</li> 
        <li>Fessej Rock</li> 
        <li><a href="/wiki/Fungus_Rock" title="Fungus Rock">Fungus Rock</a>, (<i>Il-Ä ebla tal-Ä eneral</i>) (<a href="/wiki/Gozo" title="Gozo">Gozo</a>)</li> 
        <li>GÄ§allis Rock (<a href="/wiki/Naxxar" title="Naxxar">Naxxar</a>)</li> 
        <li><a href="/wiki/%C4%A6alfa_Rock" title="Ä¦alfa Rock">Ä¦alfa Rock</a> (<a href="/wiki/Gozo" title="Gozo">Gozo</a>)</li> 
        <li>Large Blue Lagoon Rocks (<a href="/wiki/Comino" title="Comino">Comino</a>)</li> 
        <li><a href="/wiki/Islands_of_St._Paul" class="mw-redirect" title="Islands of St. Paul">Islands of St. Paul</a>/Selmunett Island (<a href="/wiki/Mellie%C4%A7a" title="MellieÄ§a">MellieÄ§a</a>)</li> 
        <li><a href="/wiki/Manoel_Island" title="Manoel Island">Manoel Island</a>, which connects to the town of <a href="/wiki/G%C5%BCira" title="GÅ¼ira">GÅ¼ira</a>, on the mainland, via a bridge</li> 
        <li>Mistra Rocks (<a href="/wiki/San_Pawl_il-Ba%C4%A7ar" class="mw-redirect" title="San Pawl il-BaÄ§ar">San Pawl il-BaÄ§ar</a>)</li> 
        <li>TaÄ-Äawl Rock (<a href="/wiki/Gozo" title="Gozo">Gozo</a>)</li> 
        <li>Qawra Point/Ta' Fraben Island (<a href="/wiki/San_Pawl_il-Ba%C4%A7ar" class="mw-redirect" title="San Pawl il-BaÄ§ar">San Pawl il-BaÄ§ar</a>)</li> 
        <li>Small Blue Lagoon Rocks (<a href="/wiki/Comino" title="Comino">Comino</a>)</li> 
        <li>Sala Rock (<a href="/wiki/%C5%BBabbar" title="Å»abbar">Å»abbar</a>)</li> 
        <li>Xrobb l-GÄ§aÄ¡in Rock (<a href="/wiki/Marsaxlokk" title="Marsaxlokk">Marsaxlokk</a>)</li> 
        <li>Ta' taÄ§t il-Mazz Rock</li>
       </ul> 
      </div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Climate">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Malta" title="Climate of Malta">Climate of Malta</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Blue_Lagoon_and_Cominotto.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Blue_Lagoon_and_Cominotto.JPG/220px-Blue_Lagoon_and_Cominotto.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Blue_Lagoon_and_Cominotto.JPG/330px-Blue_Lagoon_and_Cominotto.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Blue_Lagoon_and_Cominotto.JPG/440px-Blue_Lagoon_and_Cominotto.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2592" data-file-height="1944"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Blue_Lagoon_and_Cominotto.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Blue Lagoon Bay between <a href="/wiki/Comino" title="Comino">Comino</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cominotto" title="Cominotto">Cominotto</a> island
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Malta has a <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_climate" title="Mediterranean climate">Mediterranean climate</a> (<a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="KÃ¶ppen climate classification">KÃ¶ppen climate classification</a> <i>Csa</i>),<sup id="cite_ref-cia_26-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-26">[26]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[154]</a></sup> with mild winters and hot summers, hotter in the inland areas. Rain occurs mainly in autumn and winter, with summer being generally dry. </p>
      <p>The average yearly temperature is around 23&nbsp;Â°C (73&nbsp;Â°F) during the day and 15.5&nbsp;Â°C (59.9&nbsp;Â°F) at night. In the coldest month&nbsp;â January&nbsp;â the typical maximum temperature ranges from 12 to 18&nbsp;Â°C (54 to 64&nbsp;Â°F) during the day and minimum 6 to 12&nbsp;Â°C (43 to 54&nbsp;Â°F) at night. In the warmest month&nbsp;â August&nbsp;â the typical maximum temperature ranges from 28 to 34&nbsp;Â°C (82 to 93&nbsp;Â°F) during the day and minimum 20 to 24&nbsp;Â°C (68 to 75&nbsp;Â°F) at night. Amongst all capitals in the continent of Europe, Valletta&nbsp;â the capital of Malta has the warmest winters, with average temperatures of around 15 to 16&nbsp;Â°C (59 to 61&nbsp;Â°F) during the day and 9 to 10&nbsp;Â°C (48 to 50&nbsp;Â°F) at night in the period JanuaryâFebruary. In March and December average temperatures are around 17&nbsp;Â°C (63&nbsp;Â°F) during the day and 11&nbsp;Â°C (52&nbsp;Â°F) at night.<sup id="cite_ref-Met_Office_155-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Met_Office-155">[155]</a></sup> Large fluctuations in temperature are rare. Snow is very rare on the island, although various snowfalls have been recorded in the last century, the last one reported in various locations across Malta in 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">[156]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The average annual sea temperature is 20&nbsp;Â°C (68&nbsp;Â°F), from 15â16&nbsp;Â°C (59â61&nbsp;Â°F) in February to 26&nbsp;Â°C (79&nbsp;Â°F) in August. In the 6 months&nbsp;â from June to November&nbsp;â the average sea temperature exceeds 20&nbsp;Â°C (68&nbsp;Â°F).<sup id="cite_ref-weather2travel_157-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-weather2travel-157">[157]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-maltaweather_158-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-maltaweather-158">[158]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">[159]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The annual average <a href="/wiki/Relative_humidity" class="mw-redirect" title="Relative humidity">relative humidity</a> is high, averaging 75%, ranging from 65% in July (morning: 78% evening: 53%) to 80% in December (morning: 83% evening: 73%).<sup id="cite_ref-weatherbase.com_160-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-weatherbase.com-160">[160]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Sunshine_duration" title="Sunshine duration">Sunshine duration</a> hours total around 3,000 per year, from an average 5.2 hours of sunshine duration per day in December to an average above 12 hours in July.<sup id="cite_ref-maltaweather_158-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-maltaweather-158">[158]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-noaa_161-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-noaa-161">[161]</a></sup> This is about double that of cities in the northern half of Europe,<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:No_original_research" title="Wikipedia:No original research"><span title="The material near this tag possibly contains original research. (March 2020)">original research?</span></a></i>]</sup> for comparison: London&nbsp;â 1,461;<sup id="cite_ref-London_climate_162-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-London_climate-162">[162]</a></sup> however, in winter it has up to four times more sunshine; for comparison: in December, London has 37 hours of sunshine<sup id="cite_ref-London_climate_162-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-London_climate-162">[162]</a></sup> whereas Malta has above 160. </p>

      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Urbanisation">Urbanisation</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: Urbanisation">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Valletta,_Malta.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Valletta%2C_Malta.JPG/220px-Valletta%2C_Malta.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="150" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Valletta%2C_Malta.JPG/330px-Valletta%2C_Malta.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Valletta%2C_Malta.JPG/440px-Valletta%2C_Malta.JPG 2x" data-file-width="640" data-file-height="437"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Valletta,_Malta.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The main urban area of Malta. <a href="/wiki/Valletta" title="Valletta">Valletta</a> is the central peninsula.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>According to <a href="/wiki/Eurostat" title="Eurostat">Eurostat</a>, Malta is composed of two <a href="/wiki/Larger_urban_zones" class="mw-redirect" title="Larger urban zones">larger urban zones</a> nominally referred to as "Valletta" (the main island of Malta) and "Gozo". The main urban area covers the entire main island, with a population of around 400,000.<sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">[165]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">[166]</a></sup> The core of the urban area, the <i>greater city</i> of Valletta, has a population of 205,768.<sup id="cite_ref-Eurostat-city_167-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Eurostat-city-167">[167]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Demographia" class="mw-redirect" title="Demographia">Demographia</a>, the Valletta <a href="/wiki/Urban_area" title="Urban area">urban area</a> has a population of 300,000.<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">[168]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/European_Spatial_Planning_Observation_Network" class="mw-redirect" title="European Spatial Planning Observation Network">European Spatial Planning Observation Network</a>, Malta is identified as functional urban area (FUA) with the population of 355,000.<sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169">[169]</a></sup> According to the United Nations, about 95 per cent of the area of Malta is urban and the number grows every year.<sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">[170]</a></sup> Also, according to the results of ESPON and EU Commission studies, "<i>the whole territory of Malta constitutes a single urban region</i>".<sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">[171]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Occasionally in books,<sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">[172]</a></sup> government publications and documents,<sup id="cite_ref-creativemalta_173-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-creativemalta-173">[173]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-doi_174-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-doi-174">[174]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">[175]</a></sup> and in some international institutions,<sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">[176]</a></sup> Malta is referred to as a <a href="/wiki/City-state" title="City-state">city-state</a>. Sometimes Malta is listed in rankings concerning cities<sup id="cite_ref-GFC_177-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GFC-177">[177]</a></sup> or metropolitan areas.<sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">[178]</a></sup> Also, the Maltese coat-of-arms bears a <a href="/wiki/Mural_crown" title="Mural crown">mural crown</a> described as "representing the fortifications of Malta and denoting a City State".<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">[179]</a></sup> Malta, with area of 316&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (122&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi) and population of 0.4&nbsp;million, is one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_sovereign_states_and_dependent_territories_by_population_density" class="mw-redirect" title="List of sovereign states and dependent territories by population density">most densely populated</a> countries worldwide. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Flora">Flora</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Flora">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
      <p> The Maltese islands are home to a wide diversity of indigenous, sub-endemic and endemic plants.<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">[180]</a></sup> They feature many traits typical of a Mediterranean climate, such as drought resistance. The most common indigenous trees on the islands are olive (<a href="/wiki/Olive" title="Olive"><i>Olea europaea</i></a>), carob (<i><a href="/wiki/Ceratonia_siliqua" class="mw-redirect" title="Ceratonia siliqua">Ceratonia siliqua</a></i>), fig (<a href="/wiki/Common_fig" title="Common fig"><i>ficus carica</i></a>), holm oak (<i><a href="/wiki/Quercus_ilex" title="Quercus ilex">Quericus ilex</a></i>) and Aleppo pine (<a href="/wiki/Pinus_halepensis" title="Pinus halepensis"><i>Pinus halpensis</i></a>), while the most common non-native trees are <a href="/wiki/Eucalyptus" title="Eucalyptus">eucalyptus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Acacia" title="Acacia">acacia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Opuntia_ficus-indica" title="Opuntia ficus-indica">opuntia</a>. Endemic plants include the national flower <i>widnet il-baÄ§ar</i> (<i><a href="/wiki/Cheirolophus_crassifolius" title="Cheirolophus crassifolius">Cheirolophus crassifolius</a>), sempreviva ta' Malta (<a href="/wiki/Helichrysum_melitense" title="Helichrysum melitense">Helichrysum melitense</a>),</i> <i>Å¼igland t' GÄ§awdex (<a href="/wiki/Hyoseris_frutescens" title="Hyoseris frutescens">Hyoseris frutescens</a></i>) and <i>Ä¡iÅ¼i ta' Malta</i> (<i><a href="/wiki/Matthiola_incana" title="Matthiola incana">Matthiola incana subsp. melitensis</a></i>) while sub-endemics include <i>kromb il-baÄ§ar</i> (<i><a href="/wiki/Jacobaea_maritima" title="Jacobaea maritima">Jacobaea maritima subsp. sicula</a></i>) and <i>xkattapietra</i> (<i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Micromeria_microphylla&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Micromeria microphylla (page does not exist)">Micromeria microphylla</a></i>).<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">[181]</a></sup> The flora and biodiversity of Malta is severely endangered by habitat loss, invasive species and human intervention.<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">[182]</a></sup> </p>
      <ul class="gallery mw-gallery-packed-overlay"> 
       <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 82px">
